prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to optimise the method used by Machado et al.(2014) to measure wind velocities, we need the finest resolution. In order to fully sample the CO(1-0) absorption line, we also consider a lower resolution spectral window at the same frequency.
To enable calibration improvement, we also consider a TDM spectral window covering the same frequency as the finer resolution spectral windows.

The resolution is set by the planned configuration on 2016/May/5th. The same configuration is considered as in the other science goals, since the timing of configuration change is longer than the Mars global dust storms life-time.

Since this proposal is a target of oportunity, the exact date of observation is uncertain. We have chosen a date where Mars provides intermediate-to-good observation conditions in what apparent size and air-mass is concerned: 2016/May/5th.
Based on Cavalie et al.(2008) and Moreno et al. (2009) results, which show CO(1-0) line-absorption depths as low as ~20% of the continuum level, we request a sensitivity of 1% of the continuum level at the finest spectral resolution (30.518kHz) which is comparable to that used on those same works.
The continuum level is estimated via the Butler-JPL-Horizons 2012 model prediction. At 115.27GHz it is expected to be 419.6Jy on the temptative observation day of 2016/May/5th. Assuming the flux is homogeneously spread over the full planetary area on that day, we expect 2.17Jy/beam. Hence, we request a 21.7mJy sensitivity per 30.518kHz channel.

In order to optimise the method used by Machado et al.(2014) to measure wind velocities, we need the finest resolution. In order to fully sample the 13CO(1-0) absorption line, we also consider a lower resolution spectral window at the same frequency.
A lower resolution spectral window is also centered at C18O(1-0) to assess its detection.
To enable calibration improvement, we also consider a TDM spectral window covering the same frequency as the finer resolution spectral windows.

The resolution is set by the planned configuration on 2016/May/5th. The same configuration is considered as in the other science goals, since the timing of configuration change is longer than the Mars global dust storms life-time.

Since this proposal is a target of oportunity, the exact date of observation is uncertain. We have chosen a date where Mars provides intermediate-to-good observation conditions in what apparent size and air-mass is concerned: 2016/May/5th.
Based on Cavalie et al.(2008) results, which show 13CO(1-0) line-absorption depths as low as ~4% of the continuum level, we request a sensitivity of 0.5% of the continuum level at the finest spectral resolution (30.518kHz) which is comparable to that used on that same work.
The continuum level is estimated via the Butler-JPL-Horizons 2012 model prediction. At 110.2GHz it is expected to be 382.8Jy on the temptative observation day of 2016/May/5th. Assuming the flux is homogeneously spread over the full planetary area on that day, we expect 1.98Jy/beam. Hence, we request a 9.9mJy sensitivity per 30.518kHz channel.

In order to optimise the method used by Machado et al.(2014) to measure wind velocities, we need the finest resolution. In order to fully sample the CO(2-1) absorption line, we also consider a lower resolution spectral window at the same frequency.
To enable calibration improvement, we also consider a TDM spectral window centered at the same frequency as the finer resolution spectral windows.

The resolution is set by the planned configuration on 2016/May/5th. The same configuration is considered as in the other science goals, since the timing of configuration change is longer than the Mars global dust storms life-time.

Since this proposal is a target of oportunity, the exact date of observation is uncertain. We have chosen a date where Mars provides intermediate-to-good observation conditions in what apparent size and air-mass is concerned: 2016/May/5th.
Based on Cavalie et al.(2008) results, which show CO(2-1) line-absorption depths as low as ~20% of the continuum level, we request a sensitivity of 1% of the continuum level at the finest spectral resolution (30.518kHz) which is comparable to that used on that same work.
The continuum level is estimated via the Butler-JPL-Horizons 2012 model prediction. At 230.54GHz it is expected to be 1716.5Jy on the temptative observation day of 2016/May/5th. Assuming the flux is homogeneously spread over the full planetary area on that day, we expect 1.54Jy/beam. Hence, we request a 15.4mJy sensitivity per 30.518kHz channel.

In order to optimise the method used by Machado et al.(2014) to measure wind velocities, we need the finest resolution. In order to fully sample the 13CO(2-1) absorption line, we also consider a lower resolution spectral window at the same frequency.
A lower resolution spectral window is also centered at C18O(2-1) to assess its detection.
To enable calibration improvement, we also consider a TDM spectral window centered the same frequency as the finer resolution spectral windows.

The resolution is set by the planned configuration on 2016/May/5th. The same configuration is considered as in the other science goals, since the timing of configuration change is longer than the Mars global dust storms life-time.

Since this proposal is a target of oportunity, the exact date of observation is uncertain. We have chosen a date where Mars provides intermediate-to-good observation conditions in what apparent size and air-mass is concerned: 2016/May/5th.
There is no
Based on Cavalie et al.(2008) results, which show 13CO(2-1) line-absorption depths as low as ~5% of the continuum level, we request a sensitivity of 1% of the continuum level at the finest spectral resolution (30.518kHz) which is comparable to that used on that same work.
The continuum level is estimated via the Butler-JPL-Horizons 2012 model prediction. At 220.4GHz it is expected to be 1567.2Jy on the temptative observation day of 2016/May/5th. Assuming the flux is homogeneously spread over the full planetary area on that day, we expect 1.41Jy/beam. Hence, we request a 14.1mJy sensitivity per 30.518kHz channel.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Mars is known to sporadicly present global dust storms, which can last from days to months. During these rare episodes the dynamical properties of the Martian atmosphere has been observed to vary significantly. Nevertheless, the spatial detail and velocity precision of previous observations are coarser than those aimed by this proposal. Taking advantage of the ALMA high spatial and spectral resolutions together with its detection power, we propose target of opportunity observations, during a Martian global dust storm, tracing 12CO and 13CO (1-0 and 2-1) transitions as a means to measure wind velocities in the Martian atmosphere. Specifically, the 12CO (2-1) line will sound the 70 km atmospheric level, whereas the 13CO (2-1) line will sound the altitude of about 40km. These observations will allow us to retrieve absolute wind Doppler velocities and obtain the velocity field map that will contribute to constrain the winds' spatial coverage and inner structure during these weather phenomena. We also aim to characterise the latitudinal zonal and meridional wind profile on Mars middle atmosphere and study the wind spatial variability with respect to the latitude and local time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Instituto de Astrofisica e Ciencias do Espaco

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Instituto de Astrofisica e Ciencias do Espaco
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
